Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with diabetes following BC but I didn't have chemo.  I'm only 5 months in to managing my diabetes and my levels were sky high but within 3 months I had turned it around to be back down to pre-diabetic levels.  This means I'm still diabetic but through diet and meds (I take 1 tablet twice a day) I have normal blood glucose levels.  If I l return to my old eating habits my blood glucose levels will rise again. To achieve this I seriously reduced my carbs so potatoes, rice, pasta, bread is now restricted and I try to stay under 40-50g of carbs a day.  All carbs turn to sugar so no use just watching sugar content in body. I eat good protein, as much as I want, so chicken, butter, cream are all fine.   Also restrict root veg like swede and fruit.  On the plus side I feel so much better and everyone constantly remarks how well I look. If you are found to be diabetic pop over to this forum for tips and to show you why you need to test your blood daily - which is quite painless but the key to managing diabetes!!  https://forum.diabetes.org.uk/boards/forums/newbies-say-hello-here.12/
Posts.Title: Diabetes

Posts.Content: People self funding buy this monitor as the strips are cheaper at £8 for 50.  Cheap monitors but branded makes can often charge 2 or 3 times this for strips.  You will need to buy more strips as it's only a starter pack.  We use mmol measurement in this country. https://www.amazon.co.uk/Codefree-Glucose-Monitor-Monitoring-Testing/dp/B0068JAJFS Readings you are aiming for is 4-6 upon waking and before meals.  Under 8.5 two hours after eating though the ideal is a rise of no more than 2 on your before eating reading.  Mention was made of Hba1c test. I had this in November and it measured my average blood glucose over previous 8-12 weeks.  My level was 117 (this meant my blood glucose level was 18).  Under 42 is non diabetic, under 48 is pre diabetic.  Anything over 48 or over is diabetic.  In three months I reduced my Hba1c to 42.  My diabetic nurse was amazed as I'm not on a high level of meds.  It was all down to severely restricting carbs.  Through testing I know how much carbs I can tolerate so I know I can eat a slice of Tesco finest high protein bread without too much of an issue but ordinary whole meal bread spikes me.  Home made cakes not too bad in moderation, vegan cakes very good.  Shop bought cake and the rise is through the roof.  Fruit they say to stick to berries (I love strawberries with double cream now) but again by testing you might find that eating other fruit agrees with you. Generally fresh prepared food I tolerate better than the same ingredients in ready meals.  I eat to my meter and everyone is individual.  Some can tolerate porridge, others can't.   The good news is wine can reduce your blood glucose!    It took me almost 3 weeks to get my readings into single figures and stay there.  One thing you should be aware of is that if you are at all out of sorts or stressed it can cause erratic and high readings!  Even if I've had a wakeful night or vivid dream my waking blood sugar can be a 7 instead of normal low 5!

Posts.Content: mistymoley Just be aware that any meters are not quality controlled so their accuracy can be debatable.  My daughter works for a company called Spirit Healthcare dot com and they only sell the properly calibrated ones.  Lots of information on the website too.    Any meter you purchase or given by your healthcare team should meet ISO standards .  The SD codefree is the cheapest one meets the 2013 (the latest) standard.  It's highly recommended on forums of diabetes.org.uk if you are self funding and as we know from this forum others fighting the same battles as you are the best source of information & support.

Posts.Title: Breast cancer groups

Posts.Content: NikNic Imy absolute fear is that mine has spread (if it's already in 'multiple lymph nodes' then it seems a likely outcome to me). I *think* they pretty much told me that if it has spread they can't 'cure' me, only prolong my life a little. I need someone with a crystal ball to tell me 'this is all going to be ok' and then I will put my big girl pants on and fight, fight, fight! Others will come along who had lymph node involvement and tell you that they were doing their job and catching the cancer to stop it spreading.  They are your first line of defence, little soldiers ready to stop the assault.  Lymph node involvement is very common. 90% of BC patients survive 5 years ago and remember this statistic is based on using at least 5 year old treatments, the treatments for cancer move a apace so you will be having more modern, targeted treatment.  Of the 10% who don't make it they may have other health conditions or even old age which contributed to their death. So go find your big girl pants and pull them up high but first be kind to yourself and allow yourself to grieve for your former "carefree" life.  You will be showing your children valuable life lessons.  It will be good for them to see that you are not always strong and sometimes you need to lean on others.  It will make you more human and approachable when they come to you with their life issues as they will know you will understand what it is to feel scared etc.

Posts.Title: Women in France - scarves in schools

Posts.Content: Doesn't life feel cruel and unfair when this happens.  I didn't feel angry or why me but I was numb, scared and silently tearful.  I hated having to deal with other people's reactions to my news.  People can say the most inappropriate things and I know they mean well and want to offer moral support but it can come across as flippant, patronising or just plain selfish.  There are friends who over a year on from my diagnosis that I've never told as I can't face their reaction.  I still get the tilted head "Of course you know how awful it is" when someone mentions x has been diagnosed with cancer.   I had surgery last July and this week I've had a sore boob.  I've always had sore boobs that comes and goes.  I had a mamo in April and all clear but still niggling in the back of my mind, "what if".  As I'm typing this my good boob has decided to ping me some pains!! The waiting for you now is the worst bit.  You are scared, your diagnosis is unknown, your treatment plan if needed unknown.  You may be tempted to google - I did and it didn't help.   Like others on this site said, once you know your treatment plan, timescales it all becomes easier.  I only had surgery and radiotherapy, no chemo.  All my treatment went to plan, my breast care nurse after surgery was fantastic - BCN can make so much difference to how you cope.  My BCN went first diagnosed and attached to the screening unit was not my cup of tea and I didn't find her supportive or helpful.  Loved, loved my second one though. So good luck with scans next week.  The good thing is they don't keep you waiting.  As other's have said 9/10 women with BC will be cured.  You will be in that 9 x

Posts.Content: My hubby fell last year and was hospitalised for a few months.  He had all the positive comments while lying flat on his back for 6 weeks but a funny thing happened when this man came on to the ward feeling seriously ill with his entourage of wife , children and grand children telling everyone how he’d fallen off a ladder and had a back brace because he’d hurt his back .  He then walked from bed to bed  and  asked the man in next bed why he was in and he said he’d fallen off a ladder and broken both ankles.  He was ok with this as he thought his back brace top trumped him.  The other two had bone infections  so he felt he was the winner then he got ti my hubby who had spent the last few weeks flat in his back with a neck brace and unable to sit up when to eat !  I think he thought he was having a nap and was like what you done Mate!  He had broken his back and neck in 5 places, damaged his spinal cord and cut his head open down to the skull!  He was in this hospital for 6 weeks and then off to a spinal unit for rehab.  Hubby top trumped!   Then hubby goes to a spinal unit where they would get him walking but as with all patients until they had physio etc and were passed fit to walk unaided he had a wheelchair.  He wheeled himself to introduce himself to the other residents - there were about 10 of them on his section of ward all with various spinal issues but he laughed when one asked him what he done and he said fell 15 foot into concrete waterway etc.  and he said what about you !  He’d fallen over 30 foot off a cliff landed face down and broken his back and damaged his spine seriously!  Hubby just said ‘ well that’ top trump’

Posts.Content: Being told you have cancer is the pits!  You lose all sense of reason and are planning your goodbyes.  I'm so sorry you lost your mother so young but as others pointed out diagnosis and treatment has moved on. When I was told I had cancer I panicked.  My mother died 1988 from bowel cancer, weeks after being diagnosed and then three years before my diagnosis my sister died a month after being diagnosed with a brain tumour.  I was so scared that the same fate awaited me, dead in weeks.  But statistically speaking 90% of people survive breast cancer and that's based on people treated 5 years ago.  So here I am 2 years later - still niggling away at me at times but I've come out the other side.  You will come out the other side but you need to allow yourself to grieve for your "cancer free" life before you can accept that you will have a new "after cancer" life. This site is so good for letting out your dark, scary and sometimes twisted humour thoughts.  I can remember being so scared when they said I would have a wire put in my boob prior to surgery but then when she told me I would lie on a table, face down, with my boob hanging through a hole in the table and they would raise it up and work underneath me to mammogram and insert the wire!  The mere thought of this made me laugh that I was like car up on ramps with them on a trolley underneath working on me.  When I told others they didn't seem to find it as amusing as me but I guess we accept that like childbirth we've lost our dignity with our boobs constantly out on show and must be quite a sight for them to see boob hanging through hole!  Good luck with your scans and future treatment.  Know that improved imagining and testing means that with your treatment they can be meticulous in getting clear margins which might not have been the case with your mother. xx

While they too are impacted it's you it's happening to, it's you that you need to concentrate on at this point it time.  Is it selfish, maybe, but it's what you need to do for a while. As  you will have notices you will have up and down days.  You will have periods of positivity and periods of negativity.   They are your emotions and you can't turn them on and off at request.  You can put on your game face for short periods but you cannot sustain it to please others. I was just starting to think that 2016 is almost done and it's been a better year health wise for me when I get hit with type 2 diabetes!  I was upset, angry - I think I still am to a lesser degree.  I feel my body is letting me down big time.  My hubby knows to give me space when I don't want to talk and I don't want to pretend to be jolly. Dealing with other people's emotions is draining but when you feel you can explain to your family how low you sometimes feel and that you just need to work through it.  You will get through this and you will smile again xx

Posts.Content: Welcome both.  I was diagnosed with DCIS exactly 4 years ago on June 3rd 2015.  Just to reassure you I survived !!!!! i know you are feeling scared and numb st the sane time wondering if you have a future.  You do but you will change your priorities going forward as being told you have cancer really focus you on what’s important.  E.g here I am at 55 taking early retirement just because I can and there is more to life than working :) You will get people who don’t know what to say telling you that you are lucky !!!! Funny but I didn’t and still don’t feel lucky!!! Just tell them it’s a big desk being told you have cancer and you need space to process.   The waiting is the worse but treatment moves in stages and you just have to get through it.  I went to New York after biopsy results and before surgery- highly recommend as you are away from well meaning family and friends who can’t help but treat you as a victim.   So my treatment was surgery - lumpectomy (also called WLE wide local excision). I had 11 mm area removed from top of left breast and no significant dimple and invisible scar.  I had wire guided surgery witch meant under a local a fine guide wire inserted in the morning - less painful than biopsy. Then general surgery in afternoon and home in the evening.  I didn’t require any painkillers once home.  Then 6 weeks after surgery 15 daily sessions of radiotherapy - took a few minutes daily for 3 weeks.  Painless procedure just need to keep skin moisturised.   I took sick leave from biopsy till a few weeks after rads ended.  Working through is possible if job accommodating but I chose to just focus on me and my physical and mental well being .  You can read my bio for more info since .

Posts.Content: On the positive side you had a clear mammogram last year so if there is something it's been picked up quickly. I was recalled age 51 after first routine mammogram.  There were 5 of us at recall clinic which was a one stop repeat mammo, doctor and then if necessary biopsy. We were all together waiting and it was a very long morning for me as I was fifth in the queue.  So here's what happened.  We all had repeat mammo then sent to wait.  Then called in one by one to see doctor. Lady no. 1 told they wanted to biopsy a lump so off she went for her biopsy.  I think they told her they were sure it was breast cancer by the look on her face but she was trying to be brave for the other 4 of us waiting. Lady no. 2 on her second recall, she had been recalled and biopsied 6 months previous.  Doctor told her what they had seen before was no longer there so she was free to go home Lady no. 3 Doctor told her she had a harmless cyst.  She was free to go home Lady no.4 She was told she had early breast cancer and needed a biopsy. Me no.5.  I was told I had 2 very small areas of breast calcifications and she was 99% positive they were benign but biopsy to be sure.  Had biopsy and results 1 week later.  One area benign the other DCIS which is very early BC.  I was told I would have lumpectomy and if necessary hormone tablets.  I just had surgery and radiotherapy.  No chemo.  This was 2 years ago. The waiting is the worst but I "knew" from when they did biopsy it was cancer, more by radiographer's behaviour and what she said, or didn't say. You will feel better once tomorrow is over with and if it's not good news it's been caught early and is very treatable.  Good luck and let us know how you get on.  We love it when people post back with good news.

Posts.Content: Altolady the people who object to this campaign know you and other "brave" shavers do not mean to offend and it's fabulous that you want to raise money. It's just this campaign seems ill thought out.  I current have a facebook friend "braving the shave" and the temptation to ask her not to is hard to resist.  I also have to face a poster in the tea room in work of another "brave" shaver!  Again I've bitten my tongue but I won't give to sponsorship going around as my protest and I'm waiting to be asked why!!! It's hard to find ways to raise money that will incite people to sponsor you.  After we lost my sister to Brain tumour we raised over £3000 for Maggies through an auction, raffle, family day etc.  Maggies barely acknowledged our donation, in fact their response felt quite rude and impersonal so now we don't give to Maggies instead we choose to support Brain tumour research.  My point, people are fickle about what they give money to and I know from telling family and friends I dislike this campaign ti's made them think twice about supporting it. You should do what you feel is right for you but as you have already said you feel conflicted as you don't want to upset anyone.  Maybe ask anyone who may see your campaign if they are offended and if they can suggest other ways for you to raise money. I'm tempted to do my own "dying to live" event and dye my hair a bright colour for a month to just draw attention to the fact I'm fund raising.  I'm early 50s and have a professional job so will raise some eye brows - at least I have eyebrows to raise lol!

Posts.Content: A poor response that clearly shows little understanding of how cancer patients feel.  I still remember being diagnosed and then realising just how many cancer advertisements were bombarding me when I was trying to have a break from thinking about cancer.  Go shopping and ads and collection boxes, watch some TV, more adverts, listen to the radio, Adverts.   Plus of course Facebook with it's constant MacMillan adverts because facebook knows you've been on the MacMillan site.  I even get mail shots from MacMillan asking me to donate.  It's constantly in my face at home, work etc.  No respite. I didn't undergo Chemo so never lost my hair but I wouldn't dream of patronising someone who has by saying "I'll shave my hair to be like you".  Within a week my hair is regrowing and I still have my eyebrows, eyelashes, body hair etc.  Sadly for them they have to continue to be the "bald person" for quite a while longer while the person who has "joined in" gets praise while the cancer patient gets pity. Fundraisers just because you know someone who had cancer doesn't mean you know how they feel.  We hide so many of our true feelings from family & friends to spare them or to try to remain some dignity and not always be talking about cancer. I'm also incredulous if another poster is correct that you spend £25,000,000 on fundraising activities.

Posts.Content: It's misinformation to hide the fact we are being poisoned by pollution, food packaging, cleaning chemicals, GM food etc. most of which are outside our control. Women who can't conceive are told to lose weight, eat healthily yet lazy, smoking, overweight, macdonalds loving women can pop them out from one night stands! I've obviously got a disgraceful lifestyle because after recovering from BC I now have type 2 diabetes!  I'm 5lb overweight according to NHS charts.  I've always been more inclined towards vegetarian food as I'm not very keen on meat but love pasta, rice etc.  The diabetic nurse introduced me to the Eatwell plate which is the worse thing I could eat as a diabetic.  I now follow a low carb diet so no rice, pasta or potatoes and 1 slice of bread a day max.  I eat double cream, butter, sauce laden chicken and tofu.  I've lost a little weight but the scales don't show that my waist is 2" smaller and my bra a size smaller.  My blood sugar is now in non diabetic range when 2 months ago I was 3 times over the this. The fact is that our genes are responsible for how our bodies deal with health issues.  To be type 2 diabetic you need the gene.  Many cancers they have found a gene that increases your risk. But hey it's easy for the medical profession and politicians to feed the media with blaming patients.  If it was lifestyle every fat person would be diabetic and cancer riddled!

Posts.Title: loss of autonomy

Posts.Content: I think everyone hates the thought of surgery but it is literally one minute you are being told to count or something and the next  you are awake!! I've had 3 surgeries in my life, the first age 7 when parents were not allowed to stay with children in hospital so I saw my mother at 9pm and at 8am the following morning a nurse came and put a hat on my head and two porters to take me to theatre - I still remember them telling me off for crying like a baby!!!! Second one was emergency C-Section and all I remember is them saying we will be waking you soon to see your baby!!!  No time to think. Third one was 3 years ago - lumpectomy and I was struck by how nice and calm they all were.   I had been hanging around all day and finally at 3pm they came to get me.  They told me to bring my pillow.  I was then handed over to the theatre nurse who took me into her little side room to check she had the right person;  I was hugging the pillow like a teddy bear.  She was amazing, as if by magic she realised I was on the point of breaking down when she said "okay off we go". Then into the theatre room which didn't look very medical and technical and I met the anaesthetist again - he had come to speak to me earlier to see how I had been after previous anaesthetic.  The theatre nurse was still with me and was amazing at distracting me - she  had me sit up to put electrodes on my back while he was putting in IV access and I didn't notice him doing it and that's the last I remember until I woke up.  This was the only part that was the same as my previous two surgeries - I remember waking up and seeing the clock - it was 4.50!  Previous surgeries I woke at 1.30pm and 7.45pm!!  Strange what you remember!! So good luck for tomorrow, be nice to be cancer free after surgery xx

Posts.Content: What an awful saga to get your results.  I too would be furious if this happened to me. I had my original results from biopsy a week after my recall, they gave me an appointment the day they took biopsy and I met my surgeon who outlined first stage of treatment (surgery) and what may follow depending on results from surgery biopsy. After surgery I was told results would be 2 - 3 weeks.  I saw my BC nurse 2 days after surgery and she told me as soon as they came through she would let me know.  I saw her a week later and she said she was off for the next two days but the other BC nurse was aware I was awaiting results.  Friday afternoon at 4.30pm the other BC nurse rang me to say she had my results and wanted to let me know before the weekend.  The results were good, clear margins though and no invasive cells but it was high grade DCIS not intermediate.  I cannot tell you how grateful I was for that phone call.  Maybe if the results had been worse I would have been called to an appointment but my BC nurse is wonderful and understands how stressful patients find waiting so I think she would have rang me or called me to see her that day to talk them through.
Posts.Title: Serously not impressed...

Posts.Content: I was referred to a one stop clinic after my first screening mammogram showed areas of concern. My appt. was 9.45am and I was patient number 5.  The other 4 women had earlier appts. but we all waited together. They were all recalls and we had a repeat mammogram and then sat in a small waiting area for the Doctor to turn up to read the films.  For some reason she was an hour late and didn't turn up till 10am. Then one by one we were called in for her verdict!!  First one in was told she had to have biopsy, second one in was told she could go home, number 3 biopsy, number 4 go home and me biopsy!! I had a lot of waiting around and my hubby was in the exterior waiting area as they don't allow men in to the clinic waiting area as there were 5 women with just a cape covering their top halves! I had my biopsy about 12pm.  I was sat in a chair with my boob in the mammogram machine.  They took 6 samples and then released me and moved to another site on my breast and took another 6 samples.  I can honestly say after getting used to the boob being clamped for first go - radiographer was right you get tolerance quite quickly I had a local and off they went.  I had no pain at all and there was radiographer just dedicated to talking to me and keeping me calm while the other 2 did the deed. I asked for top up of local anaesthetic so had 3 lots all together as I don't see why I should risk pain !!!  Afterward I wasn't sore at all and never needed painkillers. I guessed by comments the radiographers  made that they knew it was likely to be cancer A week later I returned for results and one area was malignant but the other area was benign.  6 weeks later surgery to remove the naughty area, then 6 weeks later radiotherapy. No chemo or hormone treatment for me.  I have had my first annual check up and it was clear thankfully. I was lucky I got off lightly with treatment though I didn't feel very lucky at the time when they told me I had cancer.

Posts.Content: I was reminded recently how horrid the waiting is.  Three years ago I was recalled from my first routine screening and those 3 weeks were the longest to find out what they were looking at.  At the follow up appointment it was a one stop clinic so repeat mammogram and biopsy of two areas. One area was benign the other not.  Surgery and radiotherapy and breathe! Roll forward 3 years and I went for my three year anniversary mammogram and had results straight away.  There was an area of concern in my good boob and they did an ultrasound and biopsy there and then.  Then back home to wait 5 days for results.  Call never came as promised so I had to ring.  Biopsy fine but they wanted to rescan.  Another week of waiting for new scan.  Thankfully all fine and I'm clear for another year but the waiting around really got to me.  I was so angry they didn't ring as promised with biopsy results, surely if they knew how hard the waiting was they would ring when promised. My little tip for a mammogram is to count to 20 once they have clamped your boob.  You won't get to 20 as it will release before then and I find it a sort of self hypnosis to make it easy to get through (I have big boobs so they really squash them).  I have biopsy on two occasions, first time 12 samples taken, second time just 2.  I did not find them painful during or after and needed no painkillers.  First time I had two injections of local so boob very numb, second time I only had one injection of local but felt nothing at all.and she was super quick so done in a few minutes.  Good luck with your appointment.  It will soon come round but no harm ringing see if they have a cancellation.  They got me one for my follow up mammogram a couple of weeks ago as they send me an appointment for 28th October

Posts.Content: Almost 10 years ago (when I was 42) I felt a swelling under my left arm pit.  I was referred to breast clinic within 2 weeks.  They did a mammogram and then called me in and told me it was a "fat pad" and did an ultrasound to confirm.  I was so relieved. However when I was called for my first routine screening in May this year I was recalled due to suspicious areas on my left breast.  First I knew they were interested in left side was only being mammogrammed on this side.  I had to wait then to see doctor to be told what they would do next.  I worried they had missed something all those years ago but they hadn't. I had a biopsy that same day.  I didn't find it painful at all as I had a local anaesthetic prior to the biopsies being taken.  Worst part was sitting there with my boob clamped in mammogram machine but you get used to the pressure quite quickly.  They took multiple samples from 2 sites but after I had local injection I felt nothing.   I had to wait a week for results and yes it was cancer, but early stage cancer. I have now surgery to remove the offending area and finish radiotherapy next week.  I did not need Chemo. I took my husband with me when recalled but he could not come in with me as they operate the breast clinc as a group session so 4 other women sitting there with the wonderful capes on.  Of the 5 of us recalled only 1 had a lump you could feel, the rest of us were just recalls from routine scanning.  2 people were sent on their way - 1 told what they had seen on routine mammogram had disappeared and second who had lump had a cyst.  Three of us had biopsies.  I don't know their results but one said she had been told before biopsy she had early stages BC as it was evident from the pattern they could see.  I was told I probably just had breast calcification (which is benign)..

Posts.Content: Reading on another thread about a member's sister saying she wished she had BC instead of being a widowed made me think about my own diagnosis and what I would /wouldn't wish on myself or someone else. While I was waiting for my biopsy results I kept some sanity by thinking "rather me than my daughter or a child" and I truly meant it. I lost my mother to colon cancer, my sister to brain cancer. 30 years ago the treatment and survival rate for colon cancer was poor but has improved dramatically so today my mother would have survived.  Primary brain cancer still has poor survival rates. My gran had BC at age 70 and lived a fit and active life for 20 years after having 2 radical mastectomies 4 years apart and a recurrence.  Her doctor was right that old age would get her not the cancer.  She never got over the unfairness though of her living such a long life while losing 2 of her children to colon cancer.  I have other female relatives who have had BC and they are all 10+ years survivors. When my sister was diagnosed she kept saying she never expected this she always thought she would get breast or colon cancer. Posts.Title: Waiting for breast core biopsy results and reading too much into available...

Posts.Content: I had a recall from my first routine mammogram at 51 last May.  I had no symptoms or lump.  I had a repeat mammogram and then a core biopsy of  two areas they need to check out.  I had micro calcifications one 10mm and the other much smaller.  The Dr who told me I needed a biopsy said she 99.9% sure they were just calcifications.  The radiographers doing the biopsy made me think they were not so innocent as she asked the Dr if she wanted her to leave clips where she had taken the biopsy from.  I asked what the clips were and she said it was in case they came back to look at that area and they could easily pin  point where they had biopsied.  The Dr said no.  I had 6 samples taken from each area, so 12 in total and they commented when they had a "good" sample with calcification! A week later I had my results.  The larger area was DCIS intermediate grade, the smaller area was benign.  My treatment was a WLE (lumpectomy).  I asked them to remove both areas for peace of mind.  The surgeon said she could achieve a good cosmetic result by removing both areas as my breast were on the large size (I'm a 36/38 G).  I have a small scar, barely 1" on top of my left boob and a small dent when I lift boob up. Following surgery they upgraded my DCIS to high grade but no invasive cells so treatment plan continued to 15 sessions of radio therapy.  I had been told if my lump had been positive for hormones then I would have had 5-10 years of drug therapy (it's good and bad that I didn't need drugs!!).  I did not require Chemo as it's not necessary for DCIS.  I had my first annual review the end of April and the mammogram should no areas of concern :) DCIS is early stage cancer and my surgeon did explain to me that some think it's over treatment to remove it and that it may never turn into fully blown cancer and they could just watch it.  However as mine was high grade I'm happy they treated it as it's the mostly likely to turn into invasive cancer. Do you know the size of area they are concerned about?  If you do get bad news then DCIS is the best of bad news!  Hopefully though you will get good news but ask them how often they intend to check that it remains as micro calcifications.  I do realise you would prefer to hear, it was all clear :) :) :)  but on this site you only tend to get the other side as that's why most remain posting on this site.  So for me saying it was DCIS there could be 100s out there who were told it's benign, but they don't post on here. Good luck for next week and let us know how you get on x

Posts.Content: Come on now, your mother has accepted that until she has finished treatment she is living with cancer, not  dying from it. She has stage 1 which is the lowest stage so her prognosis is excellent.  She maybe outwardly showing she is calm but inside she might be paddling like mad but because you are not handling it well and she knew you wouldn't handle well so she can't lean on you.  Sorry but now is the time to step up to the mark and show her you can cope and can support her.  You've already started this process by attending an appointment with her so you can do it. When I was waiting for results of my biopsy I didn't want to tell my 20 year old daughter who was away at uni as I didn't want to upset her and I didn't want to have to deal with her upset while I was still in limbo and it might have all been for nothing.  When I was told that it was cancer and they started to outline the proposed treatment they remarked how calm I was but they didn't see me the moment I sat in my car!!!  That same day I drove to tell my daughter and we cried together, it was good to get it out.  The Breast care nurse came out to see us as a family 2 days later by which time we had all talked and had questions to ask.  It was so good to have this as my husband and daughter were so positive and supportive about my treatment and I didn't have to worry about how they were coping and that took so much pressure off me.  So sit and talk to your mother and if necessary cry together.  Get it out and then talk about how you are going to deal with it.  Use positive language with her about how she is going to get through this, remind her of the 90% 5 year survival rate for Breast cancer and how at stage 1 she's in an excellent position.  I had surgery and radiotherapy, no chemo so my treatment was done in less than 6 months.   I am back working full time and my only issue is fatigue but I'm fine apart from that.  Start with practicalities for your mother.  After surgery she may need different bra depending on her boob size, what sort of surgery  she has, where the scar is etc.  I am a G cup and I have a 1" scar on top of my boob.  I had no nodes removed so could wear underwired again and as it was essential I had support so no pulling down on my scar this is what I did but for radiotherapy bigger boobs often come off worse with the skin underneath causing problems and underwired bras can rub skin that is a bit tender so I bought the stretchy step into bras to wear plus post surgery bras as they are soft cotton inside and normally have less seams to rub on skin. She will probably only be hospital for the day but if sent home shouldn't be alone for 24 hours so can she stay with you or you with her.  I remember feeling amazingly well the day after surgery but complete sh!t the following day.  Then the waiting began again for results of biopsy from surgery and I was very stressed as you are told  your treatment can change or you need further surgery depending on the results so try not to leave her alone with too much time to think.  You can and will do this.  Tell your children what is going on as they too can support their gran.  I so appreciated the support of my extended family and one of my nieces was amazing not only to me but to my daughter as well.

My daughter took the news very well.  Tears at first but then her sensible head on.  I had my first annual review last week and I was so stressed in the days before - it took me by surprise how awful I felt.  Thank fully all well.  It's always there hanging over you and if you have family or friends who have suffered with cancer make contact with them as they will be a great support as they understand completely how you feel.  I assume your daughter is an adult so I think she has to step up to the mark and support you and you need to stop worrying about her feeling and concentrate on  your treatment.   I didn't over share with my daughter but I didn't totally hide my stress and sometimes just told her "I'm down" or "I'm scared".  Sometimes just giving voice to your feelings helps. There is lots of support on this site if you need it  Good luck with your treatment xx
Posts.Title: How are you all so brave, I've just been diagnosed

Posts.Content: Sorry you find yourself here.  Don't beat yourself up for not going sooner, it's in the past now you deal with the present and the future.  I had no lump and was diagnosed following my first routine screening.  15 months on I've been back in work full time since January so know you will get through this.  Hearing the word cancer is so, so hard and it does change something in you for ever but the new you can be as good as the old you.  At my recall I had a second mammogram on the breast they were interested in followed by a Stereotactic biopsy where I sat in a chair at mammogram machine.  I had local anaesthetic so procedure was painless.  A week a I had result then 3 weeks later surgery to remove a lump of tissue  followed by radiotherapy.  I didn't need chemo.    Sadly the waiting will do your head in, nothing can be done about it as it's a step by step process which determines the next stage of your treatment. You will find lost of advice and support on this forum so keep posting. Good luck xx

Posts.Content: If it is cancer or even if they are just unsure and want to remove the lumps they may offer you a double reduction! I would say though consider this option as I wasn't expecting to be offered it so had to make my mind up within days.

Posts.Content: I think most people accept that complimentary therapy is not for everyone.  Some of these complimentary therapies may work by placebo effect or they may actually make a difference.  It's great that people's minds are not closed to the possibility but I think we all know there are no miracle cures out there. I have spent a life taking supplements! None prevented me getting BC in June this year.  For the record these are the supplements I take: Started: 20 years ago - Quest Agnus Castus for very heavy periods (worked amazingly wish I had discovered as a teenager) 15 years ago - New Foods Vit D-3 2000/5000 iu.  Initially for my daughters eczema.  Cleared it up and recommended to a friend for her son and also worked for him.  I take as I work in an office and often feel like a troglodyte when I leave the office.  5 years ago - Low dose asprin as preventative measure as two close relatives had bowel cancer and it's recommended for over 50s.  I just started a few years earlier. 2 weeks ago - New Foods Curcumin - anti inflammatory, colon help, affect on cancer cells and good for joints (I have broken bone in foot) On and off - multi vit/mineral when I'm feeling low and feel my diet is lacking.  I have never eaten red meat or fish.  I have limited dairy - only eat cheese and butter, never knowingly eat margarine.  I have always been a water drinker, long before it was fashionable as I just like it.  Love most vegetables but especially spinach and cabbage!  Can't live without chocolate though! I expect no miracles from any of my supplements but they make me feel I'm trying and helping myself.  I would never use them to replace conventional medicine for serious illnesses but would for non life threatening illnesses - like eczema.  I am not a fan of routine use of pain killers as I believe we have pain for a reason.  I have a chronic bad back and the pain reminds me not to over do things but I'm not a martyr to it and if necessary will take a time released painkiller to enable me to sleep at night.  When my daughter was young I followed my mother's advice of not to rush to reduce temperature with medicine as a high temperature is the body's way of killing off a virus.  Instead I kept her close, mopped her brow and monitored her closely till her fever subsided.   That's not to say I never used calpol but I tried to limit it's use.  I have also never rushed to use antibiotics for either myself or my daughter.  Again thanks to advice from my mother many years ago and my husband who both took on very early advice that we would build résistance to them. I tried acupuncture for horrendous hayfever.  It didn't work at all.  I also tried local honey (God I hate honey)- again it did nothing.  After trying numerous conventional medication from GP finally found a combination that worked for me (steroid nasal spray, eye drops and tablets).  I didn't like the idea of steroid nasal spray but have a friend who is a pharmacist (and an alternative medicine practioner) and she explained the dose was so small it wasn't harmful if used with care.  I think I'm an average person, with an average attitude to complimentary therapies.  They may or may not work but you should always take care that they do not interfere with your medication and that they are from a reputable supplier. Remember  many years ago people were laughed at when told the world was round and not flat!

Posts.Content: My BCN was/is wonderful.  From day 1 of her taking on my care after surgery she gave me a leaflet explaining her role and saying she was now my "advocate".  Anything I wanted I just had to ring her.  I did ring a few times and had her answerphone but she always rang me back same day and even if she answered me on phone would offer me the chance to go and see her -never later than the day after.  Everytime I saw her she offered moral support, she was always honest about what could happen but never in a scary, overwhelming way.  There is a second BCN attached to the unit and technically I wasn't her patient but my BCN told me if she was on leave the other one was available and in fact when my pathology results came through after surgery and my BCN was on leave for a couple of days the second BCN rang me late Friday afternoon to tell me them as my BCN had asked her to if they came though.  Such a small act but as they were good results it lifted me for the weekend. I was also given information about Maggie's centre where I could access other services if needed.  https://www.maggiescentres.org/our-centres/ You have been through so much and your BCN is there to support you so don't feel afraid to contact her again and ask her to direct you for counselling support.  You are not a nuisance and if she has an attitude problem that's her problem not yours.  I hope you get the support you need and best wishes for a lovely Christmas x

Posts.Title: Lumpectomy with breast reduction - when might this be offered?

Posts.Content: Sadly we have all been in your shoes waiting for results.  It really is relentless.  I had routine mammogram, my first at 51, then 3 weeks later saying "we can't give you your results yet, come back in a week".  Then when I went back to "one stop clinic" a week later the doctor was an hour late to clinic so almost 3 hours waiting before I was told what their concerns were.  Had biopsy then told to come back a week later.  Before surgery my first BCN who wasn't so helpful told me 40% of patients had to go back in for further surgery as they didn't get clear margins.  So after waiting 5 weeks for surgery I then had to wait another 10 days for results of biopsy on the tissue they removed thinking I had 50/50 chance of more surgery - they second BCN told me it was actually 20% .  Get the results, which were clear margins though they upgraded diagnosis and on to radiotherapy.  Still no relaxing though as suddenly first annual mammogram is upon me and the worry started again.  Now I'm 18 months down the line and I see no one so I have this niggle that something could be going on as I had no symptoms first time. Once you know what you are facing and treatment plan it will be easier because as you say the not knowing is awful. My first BCN didn't have much of a manner about her and told me I was too matter of fact in accepting my initial diagnosis.  I found her solemn voice quite off putting.  My second one who was attached to my surgeon was much nicer.  She was open and honest but positive.

So if your surgeon leaning towards mastectomy is it because he thinks you will be lopsided after another lumpectomy rather than concern over type of cancer ?

Posts.Content: Crop top bras are actually meant to be stepped into and pulled up (like a swimsuit).  Once someone told me this I bought a few as I could never had got them down  over my head my G cup boobs without lots of painful squishing!  Cheap places to buy are Sainsbury's, Asda.   Sizing, don't be tempted to go a size up, if you are normally a medium go medium as they have a lot of give in them and you need support for good boob. If you can get nice cotton lined ones even better. I didn't have a mastectomy but bought mastectomy bras from Debenhams in sale for use during radio therapy as they were cotton line, soft and comfy.
Posts.Title: Bra advice after surgery

Posts.Content: A few years ago my hubby had an interview for ESA.  My advice is take someone with you.  They will not be allowed to talk for you but a familiar face might help.  Do not feel  you have to put on an act - many people feel they need to say the positives as if to show they are not an incompetent idiot. You are recovering from a serious illness and it's okay to not be okay.  From memory they have a set of questions to assess how you function day to day like bathing, dressing, cooking, socialising, memory, following instructions, walking, driving.  Be honest.  Someone said you should tell them how you feel on your worse days if they are more prominent than good days but if you are genuinely unwell you shouldn't need to lie.  If you are struggling with their questions you can tell them they are overwhelming you, you can't think straight etc.  We were told their first question is always a trick question like when you walk in they say "Hi how are you today" knowing that British people typically respond with "fine" or "Hi, did you find/get here alright".  Can't remember if that happened.  When you arrive at reception they ask if you wish to claim travel expenses - so if you need to pay taxi/bus ask for receipt.  We never claimed as I drove so not sure if there is limit on what they pay. My husband had to go to appeal - turns out they had someone else's medical records mixed up with his.
Posts.Title: Capability to work intwrview

Posts.Content: I had my 2 year one last Wednesday. Unlike my year 1 mammogram no results on the day, they will be sent to me.  However I'm paranoid it means something.  There were a few women there before me and some went into to see the Registrar after mammogram and some sent home. Then last night I had a dream that they told me I needed more surgery.  It's shaken me up because the day I had my results to years ago I had a dream that was so accurate. My dream was 5 people in a room and they told me I had one benign and one malignant area.  My results were exactly that and at one point there were 5 of us in the room (surgeon, nurse, sister, me and my hubby). Also is it normal to just have mammogram and no physical check. First year mammogram I then saw doctor and had physical exam.  This time just told to get dressed and go home.
Posts.Title: 2 yearly mammogram tomorroe

Posts.Content: 12 years ago I went to BC to get a lump in my left armpit checked out.  I was 41 and had mammo and ultrasound and sent home with the new it was a fat pad. Roll forward 10 years and after first routine mammogram I was recalled.  I had early BC (DCIS) in left boob, no node involvement so had surgery and radiotherapy. So hard to second guess what your symptoms mean as once you notice them they become prominent in your mind. Good luck today.
Posts.Title: Test day today!

Posts.Content: Life is sh!t at times isn't it.  I still remember that awful feeling of being told it's cancer especially since I lost my mother and sister to cancer (different ones) within a month of them being diagnosed.  But here I am over 12 months later with first all clear scan.  My gran was 70 when first diagnosed with BC, then 74 when it reappeared in other breast.   She passed away age 90 in 1990. I focus on treatment has moved on so much in over 30 years and she had 20 good years after first diagnosis.  I didn't tell my daughter until I knew my diagnosis, I hid recall, biopsy etc from her as she was in Uni.  When I had diagnosis I drove the same day to tell her.  She said she was glad I ddi it face to face.  Your children are younger but I'm sure you will find the right way to tell them you are LIVING with cancer at the moment but the doctors are going to take it away.  90% of BC are cured, you will be in that 90% because you want to be.  Positive mental attitude will help you all so much . Look after yourself xx
Posts.Title: Stage 3 breast cancer help & how to tell my children

Posts.Content: If you are well endowed you may struggle to find non wired bras/tops that provide sufficient support.  I'm an FF cup and my breast care nurse told me to ensure I had support to stop pulling on my wound. I think a lot depends on your surgery and wound location.  I had a WLE and scar on top of my breast.  I did not have any nodes removed from under my arm. I wore underwired bras after surgery but made sure they were cotton, soft and comfy.  I couldn't wear a bra for long a couple of weeks into radiotherapy as my skin was sore.  I did buy some soft post surgery bras but could only keep them on for a short period as everything irritated my irradiated skin!  I had the T shirt step into soft bras which were ok - not much support but a better than nothing.  If you have smallish boobs you will find it easier to find comfy non wired bra that give support.

Posts.Content: I understand how you feel as once you get your head together you know with BC here is hope.  I lost my sister to a brain tumour a few years before I was diagnosed. The survival rate for malignant brain tumours hasn't improved much in over 40 years and my sister had only 1 month from diagnosis.
Posts.Title: Feeling sad but lucky!

Posts.Content: This waiting is the worse you will feel.  The unknown is scary at the moment you will be swinging between "I have cancer the end" and "it will be okay" but not believing it. Well the truth is you will be okay.  Try not to anticipate the results, there are just so many possibilities.  If and I mean If it is cancer then you will get first class modern treatment.  Treatment that means 90% of women will be around to write on this site "I'm still here".   This is based on 5/10 year old statistics and treatment is improving constantly so in 5 years time it might be 95%. I had two areas biopsied and one was benign and the other DCIS.  I had a lumpectomy and radiotherapy and finished my treatment last September.  I'm still a bit scarred mentally by the last year but I am also more appreciative of life. Good luck for next Thursday and hope it's good news x

Posts.Content: Apparently I'm one of the lucky ones with non invasive DCIS.  I had WLE and radiotherapy between July and September.  Strangely I don't feel very lucky even though I know that so many people going through Chemo would have preferred my diagnosis. The word Cancer messes with your head and hangs over you.  People say "oh are brave", "you can do this", "they will cut the critter out soon and you'll be fine".  Yes I am fine but still suffering inside. I am not brave, I am not strong I'm just dealing with what life has thrown at me. Yes you will deal with this but you also need to vent your feelings.
